@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj Youba: We have a scholarship programme... to support young scientists doing a PhD on climate-related topics

@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj Joeri: If you‚Äôre a young scientist, there are a number of ways you can start engaging with the IPCC. I started as a contributing author, helping my supervisor who was a lead author to develop materials for his chapter.

@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj Youba: For the 1.5¬∫ report we had 42,000 comments and you can see them on the website and how every one was responded to. Making a comment is as important as being an author

@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj Youba: There are different ways. Any citizen can participate in an IPCC report. Be aware of the website: there are open comments for each draft. You register, you can read the report, and any comment will be responded to.
@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj #AskIPCC Final Question: How do you join the IPCC as a young scientist?
@KalinaBrowne @JoeriRogelj the endpoint is to get to zero emissions, that should be the milestone that any policy aims for

@KalinaBrowne Youba: To limit warming to 1.5¬∫C by the end of the century it‚Äôs important to reduce emissions by about half by 2030 and reach net zero by 2050 ‚Äì which requires profound transformations in all sectors ‚Äì industry, transport, agriculture, etc.
@KalinaBrowne #AskIPCC Question 5 from Instagram: What is the number 1 thing governments and leaders should and can do right now in order to fight the climate crisis?
@KalinaBrowne Youba: Climate change has contributed 1¬∫C since industrial revolution.
@KalinaBrowne #AskIPCC Question 5 from Facebook: Do we know how much natural variability there has been in temperature over the last 150 years?

@KalinaBrowne #AskIPCC Question 4 
What's IPCC doing to fund Climate Science researchers in Africa? Again, there's need to fund installation of automatic weather observing stations to increase the network of Observation Stations across Africa most especially West Africa.

@KalinaBrowne Youba: All the scenarios we assessed in the Fifth Assessment Report #AR5 considered negative emissions ‚Äì sequestration, afforestation etc‚Ä¶Part of it can be done by land, but everything can‚Äôt be done by land.

@KalinaBrowne #AskIPCC Question 3 ‚¨áÔ∏è 
To what extent is carbon sequestration part of the solution to limit temperatures rise to 2¬∞C? Is reforestation the most efficient way?

@KalinaBrowne Koko: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs never been a better time for knowledge and exchange of information and experience through all kinds of means  - we are talking to each other as human beings and experts of different backgrounds.‚Äù
@KalinaBrowne Youba: ‚ÄúAll knowledge systems are important‚Ä¶ Everything the IPCC uses must be traceable.‚Äù

@KalinaBrowne Lisa: The challenge w/traditional and indigenous knowledge is that it doesn‚Äôt cover the same format, so we have to find new ways to include it. It‚Äôs important to reach out to other disciplines where people are using it‚Ä¶ and documenting it through the scientific channels we use.

@KalinaBrowne IPCC author Koko Warner: ‚ÄúMy first research project was to do with the risks of extreme events ‚Ä¶ flooding, drought‚Ä¶ if you‚Äôre at school stay with it, it will introduce you to the most amazing conversations and friendships that will last you all our life.‚Äù
@KalinaBrowne #IPCC Vice-Chair Youba Sokona: ‚ÄúIPCC doesn‚Äôt only assess the literature and give the state of knowledge about the science.. it also stimulates knowledge production.‚Äù

@KalinaBrowne Lisa Schipper: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs vital that social scientists have a strong voice in the IPCC because we can‚Äôt resolve climate change without the humanities and other disciplines besides the social sciences.‚Äù

@KalinaBrowne #IPCC Vice-Chair Thelma Krug: ‚ÄúI was elected vice-chair‚Ä¶ and I‚Äôm thrilled to be following the work of the three working groups, and how challenging this is. Being with scientists is a world by itself .‚Äù

To ensure transparency, the First and Second-Order Drafts are made publicly available, along with the reviewer comments and the responses of the author teams to all comments, when the final reports are published.
The IPCC sets cut-off dates for literature to be accepted for publication by scientific journals, if it is to be included in the current assessment.

The drafts are not made public before the final document is approved because they are works in progress and may not yet meet #IPCC quality and accuracy standards. 

Draft text will necessarily change as review comments are addressed and the latest literature is assessed.
During the review period, access to the First-Order and Second-Order Drafts is provided to those who register as expert reviewers on condition that the drafts are not cited, quoted or distributed.
All comments submitted through this review process are addressed by authors, and a written response is provided to each comment on the First-Order and Second-Order Drafts for later publication.

The final draft of the report is distributed to governments for a final round of written comments on the SPM, before governments meet in plenary session to approve the SPM line by line and accept the underlying report.
Following receipt of the review comments, author teams then prepare final drafts of the full report, SPM and Technical Summary, taking into account review comments received.

The Second-Order Draft is also subject to simultaneous review by experts and governments. Experts who registered for the review of the First Order Draft of the report are automatically registered for this round of review; further experts may register at this stage.

After the expert review of the First-Order Draft, author teams prepare a Second-Order Draft of the report, taking into account the review comments received; a first draft of the report‚Äôs Summary for Policymakers (SPM) and Technical Summary is also prepared.

This First-Order Draft is reviewed by experts and experts are encouraged to submit comments.

The #IPCC actively encourages experts to register as reviewers to encompass as wide a range of views, expertise and geographical representation as possible.

The first draft of a report is prepared by the authors based on scientific, technical and socio-economic literature in scientific journals and other relevant publications. 

üìöThe current WGI report has over 14,000 citations.

The reports are prepared by chapter teams of authors & review editors. 

The review editors ensure that all comments received during review are given consideration by the author teams & ensure diversity in perspectives in the literature is reflected adequately in the report.
The review process includes wide participation, with hundreds of reviewers critiquing the accuracy and completeness of the scientific assessment contained in the drafts.

During the different stages of review, expert reviewers and governments are invited to comment on the scientific, technical & socio-economic assessment & the overall balance of the drafts. 

Read about the role of expert reviewers ‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/et0GYcTwpd

Multiple stages of review are an essential part of the #IPCC process to ensure a comprehensive, objective and transparent assessment of the current state of knowledge of the science related to #climatechange.

The #IPCC is committed to preparing reports for the highest standards of scientific excellence, balance, & clarity. 

#IPCC reports go through multiple stages of review before a final approval by a panel of 195 member countries.

So how does the IPCC review process work?

@Cities_IPCC @CityofEdmonton Many #IPCC bureau members and authors are taking part, including as members of the scientific steering committee. Understanding cities & #climatechange is key to our current agenda and we want #CItiesIPCC to make a major contribution to our work. #IPCC30

@Cities_IPCC Advanced remote sensing from satellites, drones, autonomous mapping vehicles and other pervasive sensing technologies, such as air quality monitoring, will be required to monitor urban processes and to efficiently map inside our buildings, and our underground infrastructure. 2/2

@Cities_IPCC A7: Many aspects of cities remain poorly understood. The biggest urban data gaps exist in the global South. For example, data on informal settlements are sparse or non-existent. #CitiesIPCC #climatechange 1/2

@Cities_IPCC Cities can also reduce risk through ensuring equitable access to basic services, improved early warning systems, more inclusive governance systems and the use of ecological infrastructure to increase the adaptive capacity of urban communities. #CitiesIPCC

@Cities_IPCC Rather cities need to adopt contextually appropriate climate-resilient development pathways that reduce energy use by employing a combination of urban density, land use mix, accessibility and connectivity, decentralized energy use, passive buildings, non-motorised transport. 2/3

@Cities_IPCC A6: There is no one size fits all in terms of urban form as cities experience different opportunities and challenges ‚Äì particularly given the high levels of informality in cities of the global South which challenge existing notions of ‚Äúthe city‚Äù. #CitiesIPCC 1/3

@Cities_IPCC A4. They should consider how lifestyle changes -- e.g. energy efficiency, use of transport -- can help tackle #climatechange and hold their decision-makers accountable for driving change. #CitiesIPCC

@Cities_IPCC 1st step in forging this global partnership will be taken in Edmonton at #CitiesIPCC where #IPCC and 9 global partners are convening over 700 scientists, practitioners and policymakers from 80 countries. 2/2

@Cities_IPCC A3: Build  global partnership between science, policy & practice focused on generating evidence-based & solution-oriented knowledge that helps  communities find local solutions to  specific climate related probs ‚Äì enabling adaptation, risk reduction & ambitious mitigation. 1/2
